Since 2018, countless Amazon workers have been killed on the job. Countless not just because the death toll is so high, but because there is evidence to suggest that many incidents have been covered up and withheld from the public eye. 2018 was also the same year Amazon brought one-day shipping to more than 10,000 cities. 
And since then, Amazon has been put on the Dirty Dozen list as one of the most dangerous employers in the entire United States. The company has repeatedly ignored safety standards and has used questionable policies to create a dystopian workplace that controls its employees through panic and anxiety, often forcing them to work through injuries, extreme heat, and even a tornado. All so that customers can get their air fryers in one day. 
But what makes working at Amazon so deadly? Well, let's examine the deaths that have been reported and see what's going on. Like in 2013, when Ronald Smith was fulfilling Amazon packages in a distribution warehouse in New Jersey and a conveyor belt jammed. According to a lawsuit from the family, Amazon demanded Herculean production. 
So to avoid a slowdown and get the conveyor going again, Ronald tried to clear it. But his arm got caught and what exactly happened next is a bit unclear. But the complaint from his family states that first he was pulled through a gap less than 6 inches wide. 
Then he fell 15 to 18 feet, hitting the concrete with his head. He was pronounced dead at the hospital due to multiple blunt force impact injuries. Then there's a worker who died at the end of November 2021. 
He approached HR and said, I'm not feeling so well, can I please go home? But he was denied because he had no time off that he could take. This is referred to as unpaid time off or UTO, which builds up the more you work. It's what employees must use if they want to go home early, take a day off for any reason, or if they're late for their shift. 
But if they arrive just 5 minutes after their start time, it's recorded as an entire hour of UTO lost as it's measured by the hour. And so this worker who was feeling too unwell to work, he had no UTO left that he could take. So it was either go back to work or be fired. 
Unfortunately, he was later found dead from a heart attack in a delivery truck trailer. To add insult to death, those who were upset by witnessing the death of their friend were told to go back to work rather than being allowed to go home or take even a moment's break to mourn. A common theme, as you'll see. 
Then there's the 61-year-old man who on December 27, 2022, collapsed from a heart attack on an Amazon warehouse floor. According to witnesses, cardboard bins were used to cordon off
the area so people wouldn't be able to see the dead body, and the warehouse went on business as usual, like nothing had happened. And it seems as though this isn't an isolated occurrence. 
It's a disturbing trend. In March of 2019, a 60-year-old picker, Joe Bowman, went into cardiac arrest. On the 911 call, a manager could be heard telling another worker to get back to work. 
Redditors claim this is a regular occurrence. On the Amazon Fulfilment Centre subreddit, a death was posted and people chimed in with their own experiences. Someone died at my fulfilment centre and work didn't stop, they just moved people from the area. 
Someone died at mine and they just put a slippery floor sign next to the body. Yep, that's what they did at my location too. And further in those comments, one employee talked about yet another death at their centre. 
From what I gathered, it was a member of the maintenance team and he was found in the bathroom on the third floor. I can't fathom how management just sent everybody back to work without so much as making a statement or addressing what was going on. But the problem isn't just how Amazon responds to deaths on the job. 
It's the company policies that may be causing these deaths in the first place. In the same warehouse of that previous 911 call, another death occurred a few months later in September of 2019, when 48-year-old Billy Foister checked into the warehouse's medical clinic, Amcare. These facilities are staffed by on-site medical representatives, or OMRs, who are supposed to be trained EMTs. 
Billy came to them complaining of headaches and chest pains. Chest pains are never something that should be ignored, by the way, and you should seek medical help right away. Amcare checked his blood pressure, said he was dehydrated, gave him beverages to drink, and sent him back to work. 
Unfortunately, a week later while on the job, he suffered a heart attack, and it took a whole 20 minutes until someone found him. They tried to administer CPR, but by the time he got to the hospital, he was pronounced dead. And this is unfortunately all too common. 
Medical concerns being brought to Amcare don't always end with death, but the seriousness of the problems are often ignored. It's why a lot of people complain about Amcare. Like on Reddit, the main complaint seems to be that Amcare is quick to give employees a clean bill of health even if their injury or symptoms are severe. 
Like one employee who allegedly received a foot injury while on the job. They iced it and told me it was a sprain and sent me back to work. I was in so much pain, but they literally were like, sprains hurt, you'll be fine. 
So I went back upstairs and finished my 12 hour shift. I even asked them if I could go home because it hurt too bad. And they said I could, but that I'd have to use my own UPT slash PTO.
They stayed home the next two days because of the pain, and struggled to get any workers' compensation. In the end, after finally seeing a doctor, they were told they had broken their foot. They really don't care about us at all, they explained. 
Of course, that's Reddit, so it's hard to validate. But OSHA, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, has investigated Amcare several times, and their findings only reinforce this worrying trend. At one warehouse, they issued a warning stating that Amazon's Amcare returned injured workers to their regular jobs, which resulted in health outcomes such as worsening of the injury, exacerbation of pain, and limited recovery from work-related injuries slash illnesses. 
Then there's also Bobby Gosfinner, an Amazon warehouse employee who spoke with CNBC for an expose on Amazon's injury rates. He described how one day the conveyor belt broke, and led to a pileup of boxes that looked like a tornado had gone through the warehouse. That took more than four hours to clear. 
Because of the twisting and bending at the rapid pace that was expected of him, he got a pain in his back. When he told his manager, the manager tried to downplay it, saying it would take a lot of paperwork. His manager asked if he could take an Advil, put ice on it, and get back to work, which he did. 
But by the end of the day, he couldn't move his right arm, and he woke up with excruciating pain the next day. Turns out, Bobby had a herniated disc. He had to wear a brace and have a surgery to get a plate and four screws surgically inserted into his neck. 
He was awarded permanent partial disability, where he got money and benefits through workers' compensation. But injuries seem all too common at Amazon fulfilment centres, which reveal a deeper problem within the company's exploitative management tactics. In 2021, the Strategic Organising Centre, a coalition of labour unions, released a report about Amazon's epidemic of workplace injuries. 
They found that compared to Walmart warehouses, a company equal to them in size and scope, Amazon had more than twice the amount of injuries each year between 2017 and 2020. And not much has changed since 2020. Senator Bernie Sanders launched an investigation in 2023 and found that Amazon's injuries were 30% more than the industry average. 
And in the Strategic Organising Centre's report from 2024, when they conducted a survey of Amazon workers, 37% of them claimed management pressured them to work before they felt ready to do so. In fact, when compared to injured workers at other warehouses, injured Amazon workers take 52% less time off to heal. But there's a deeper problem with Amcare and Amazon policies as a whole. 
It's actually stated right on internal documents that employees are not allowed to call 911. And as you can imagine, this policy has deadly consequences. On January 18th, 2013, Jeff Lockhart

While other temporary workers were let go after the holiday peak season in January, he was kept on, giving him hope for permanency, something he wanted. Amazon's internal report marked him as a consistently high performer. He was known for moving quickly up and down the aisles of the 18 football field-sized warehouses to pick all the items as fast as he could. 
Because of his speed and his size, at 6'3 and 300 pounds, he earned the nickname Tornado. Before he got the job in November, he had been jobless for a few months and desperately needed a way to support his family of three children. Two of these children were his wife's from a previous relationship. 
Yet he adopted them and treated them the same as the one child they shared together. Because of the long hours he had been putting in, he and his family were going to meet after a shift for breakfast at Shoney's, a classic American restaurant. Unfortunately, he would never make it to that breakfast date. 
At around 2.30am, he was found unconscious by an employee on the third floor in aisle A215, under shelves of heating pads and Tupperware. The employee didn't call 911. This is the procedure according to Amazon brochures. 
They state, in the event of a medical emergency, contact security with DO NOT CALL 911, all in red, underlined, and with an exclamation point. It goes on to state that security and or Amcare will provide emergency response, which goes against standard CPR protocol. One of the first steps before starting CPR is to call 911. 
Dr. Mikhail Varshavsky, better known as Dr. Mike on YouTube states, you're not actually saving someone's life by doing CPR, you're buying them time. So delaying the ambulance by even a second is extremely dangerous. But when Amcare is faced with an emergency, they may not be able to handle it. 
Many of them are EMTs, however, unlike the brochure might imply, they're limited in what they can do, as their hands are tied. As one Amcare worker explained in the Amazon FC subreddit, by law, because we lack a medical director, we are not allowed to operate at our licence level, EMT or higher, and are instead restricted to first aid only. Another Amcare worker explained 
that, one of the tricky parts is us not having great diagnostic tools. 
Even our blood pressure cuffs are the cheap automatic ones, and I'm not even sure if the pressure dial is accurate. I don't even have access to bag valve masks or Narcan. A UK Amazon employee named Mary spoke to the Tribune about how the real reason for all this is that it may be part of a cover up. 
She says that they're discouraged to call 999, the equivalent of 911 in the United States, explaining, they don't really want ambulances to come on site, sometimes they will offer to pay
for the taxi. They started doing it after there was something in the papers about Amazon calling too many ambulances at their site, likely referring to when The Guardian reported in 2018 that during the span of three years, UK Amazon warehouses called 600 ambulances. Mary also explained how a colleague of hers had signs of a stroke. 
She called her doctor, who said she would need to go to the hospital. The colleague told Amcare, and they said they wouldn't call an ambulance, and she would have to go on her own, all to keep their ambulance numbers down. So when our temporary worker, Jeff, was found unconscious at 2.30am, it took a whole nine minutes for them to finally decide to call 911. 
It took paramedics a total of 20 minutes from the moment that Jeff collapsed for them to reach him. Even though Amcare provided CPR and used the defibrillator, unfortunately, Jeff didn't make it and passed away from an irregular heartbeat, according to the medical record. Meanwhile, his wife and children had been left with grief and no means to support themselves financially. 
Jeff's father went to Amazon and asked the managers what the company would do for their son's family, and their response was, we'll see what we can do. But it seems as though nothing was ever done for them, except for some cash his fellow employees were able to gather together for the family. And it's not the only death potentially caused by the 911 policy. 
In 2018, 61-year-old Mike Golask worked at a Murfreesboro, Tennessee, fulfilment centre. First, when he was found, security was informed as per the policy, but they struggled to find a communication device, as cell phones weren't allowed. One security guard finally called 911, but then, for some reason, put 911 on hold to never return. 
Then afterward, someone else called. According to ambulance records, it took five minutes for them to call 911. Unfortunately, he died of cardiac arrest. 
Now, by this point in our investigation, perhaps you've been noticing a pattern, that many of these deaths are related to heart conditions. Well, that may be because work-related stress is known to exacerbate or even cause cardiovascular diseases and irregular heartbeats. According to the CDC, work is linked to about 10-20% of all cardiovascular disease deaths. 
They attribute it to 10 work-related factors, including long work hours, high performance demand, and low job control. Amazon warns new employees that the job will be physical, but what they don't warn them about is the stress. Due to multiple dystopian management techniques, Amazon has purposely created one of the most stressful workplaces out there. 
To start with, Amazon uses a new style of invasive surveillance in order to optimise their workforce. They've installed a vast camera system in their warehouses, which use AI to track their employees' movements. Each worker is then issued an item scanner. 
From the scanners, they are given a task, such as retrieving an item. When they pick the item, they scan it, and the scanner then records the time between scans. Once a task is done, you're
immediately given a new task, and an anxiety-inducing countdown timer starts ticking down. 
This is all according to an expected rate. You see, management sets a rate for you, which can change day-to-day, even hour-to-hour, without warning. If you're picking boxes from the shelves, it may be as high as 80 boxes per hour. 
That's 45 seconds per box. If the countdown timer hits zero before you're able to scan another box, the scanner gives you a warning that you've taken too much time off task, or TOT, and it will alert management. At one warehouse, an employee said that they only had 18 minutes a shift that they could be off task, and if they racked up too much TOT, they could be fired, a policy which has put many employees in deadly situations. 
Even bathroom breaks count towards your TOT. This means you're at a disadvantage if you need to go to the bathroom often, or if you're far from a bathroom in the massive warehouse. Author James Bloodworth investigated workplaces for his book, Hired, six months undercover in low-wage Britain. 
He worked at an Amazon fulfilment warehouse and discovered on a shelf tucked away was a bottle full of urine. He realised that the fear of getting fired led some workers to urinate in bottles in the name of efficiency. Even if it's an action that isn't directly condoned by Amazon, they've created the environment that leads to this mentality. 
Some will even purposely not intake fluids while on the job to avoid TOT, leading to dehydration. If you hydrate, eventually you've got to use the bathroom, said Stephen Hicks, an employee for Amazon. He explained how he didn't like using the bathroom outside official breaks to not hurt his rate. 
It makes me afraid, mentally and physically exhausted, said Hibek Mohamed, a stower from a Minneapolis Amazon warehouse. Workers have described the environments as Lord of the Flies-esque, where the weakest are picked off one by one. With a few mistakes, you could be terminated suddenly, with about 1 in 10 Amazon workers will get fired within the span of a year. 
If the Amazon automated system determines your productivity is low, it can even let you go without any human input. Amazon worker Danielle Olaiwola explained, You're being exploited because they know you're a hard worker, and then once you break down, they're like, Oh, well, we got a good 6-9 months out of you, you're out of here, and you're literally just used. This creates a constant low-grade panic that puts a physical and mental strain on workers every hour of the day, even during off hours. 
Hibek Mohamed added, I feel, and a lot of workers, they feel, even when they're sleeping, that they're docking to try and hit their rate. Because they're worried about next week, what's going to happen. You don't know what's going to happen. 
I don't know what I finished this week. Next week, if I hit the rate, if the rate will change. And
managers are watching you and coming to you all the time. 
You feel like someone is watching you while you're sleeping. Emily Gwendelsberger, author of On the Clock, What Low-Wage Work Did to Me and How It Drives America Insane, also went undercover at Amazon. She explained, It took my body two weeks to adjust to the agony of walking 15 miles a day and doing hundreds of squats. 
But as the physical stress got more manageable, the mental stress of being held to the productivity standards of a robot became an even bigger problem. You can't slow down if you're tired or hurting. It's why some employees have shared stories about how they've broken down crying at work. 
Speed is the priority, so they can get packages out for one or two day shipping. This leads to stress and mistakes, which leads to injuries and death. And this problem extends out to their drivers as well, who use a navigation software called Dora, or Rabbit. 
It both recommends and monitors routes for drivers, tracking their every turn. The software gives them a 30-minute lunch and two 15-minute breaks, and they're told that 999 of 1,000 packages must be delivered on time or face termination. When you're driving a delivery van, barreling down the road, the pressure to perform means there are a lot of mistakes and potential deaths involved. 
Like in August of 2022, a two-year-old girl was playing outside in a parking lot when she was fatally hit by an Amazon driver trying to get their packages out on time. She was declared dead on the scene. It left the family grieving, unable to sleep at night, saying, There are no words to describe the amount of pain. 
They wanted to sue Amazon, but they ran into an issue of liability. While they were an Amazon driver, they didn't technically work for Amazon. That's because as a means to extend Amazon's network and to keep their hands clean, Amazon has turned to outsourcing some of their deliveries to independent companies. 
They provide them with all the technology to monitor their drivers, provide routes, determine how many packages must be delivered in a day, and decide on what vans to use and how the drivers must dress. Then they leave it up to the company on how to maintain their workforce. As you might imagine, with Amazon being the majority or sometimes their sole client, these companies will do anything to keep the contract to deliver these packages, even if it's at the expense of the workers. 
As a result, they take on the deadly Amazon mentality of optimisation at all costs, without even realising it. They've been reported to have forced their workers to skip meals, urinate in bottles, speed to make deliveries, and not wear seatbelts to get out of the truck faster. This resulted in the horrific loss of an innocent life in December 2016, when a driver named Vladimir Grey flew down the Chicago roads, trying to deliver all the packages in time for Christmas.
Amazon Echo speakers were the hot item that year. They even sold out. However, in the rush, Vladimir hit Telesfora Escamilla, an 84-year-old grandmother who was walking at a crosswalk. 
He crushed her diaphragm, ribs, and skull as she lay dying in a pool of blood. He leapt out of the van and screamed, Oh my God! After police arrived, he tested negative for drugs and alcohol, and was later charged with reckless homicide, which he would be acquitted for in 2019. When the family of the deceased sued Amazon, the delivery company, Inpax, and the driver, Amazon claimed no responsibility, as it technically wasn't their driver. 
In response to BuzzFeed and ProPublica reporting on this and other fatalities caused by drivers of Inpax and two other companies, Amazon dropped these companies, further distancing themselves from blame. As a result of losing these contracts, a total of more than 2,000 workers from these companies lost their jobs. One step Amazon took to allegedly make things safer for the delivery drivers was to instal an AI surveillance system in 2021 called Netrodyn. 
It's designed to make the drivers much safer on the road by capturing violations like texting on your phone, staying too close to cars, and not using your turn signal. In theory, this should make things safer for the employees and pedestrians alike. The problem is, it tends to punish drivers for mistakes they didn't make. 
Like how one driver in Los Angeles kept getting violations for not maintaining a safe distance when he was constantly being cut off, or another who was using his phone for directions. And even with the AI surveillance system, Amazon drivers are still causing deaths on the road. In November of 2024, an Amazon driver hit and killed a 79-year-old woman who was crossing the street. 
He fled the scene and allegedly continued delivering packages. It's unclear why he kept delivering packages, but one might assume it was due to the pressures of the job. While narcotics were found in the van, there's no report of him being under the influence at the time. 
In this case, surveillance didn't help make things safer, but perhaps that's not the ultimate goal of surveillance. Like in the warehouses, it may just be another means to track their employees to make sure that speed is always the number one priority. Ultimately, it's not just one thing that contributes to these deaths. 
It's a culmination of policies, poor safety practises, and the stress-inducing environment. So will Amazon ever be held accountable for any of this? Well, not if they have anything to say about it. On September 24th, 2017, 59-year-old Phillip Lee Terry was working a shift at an Amazon warehouse in Indiana. 
He was told to fix a forklift. With a wrench in hand, he passed under the forks with a platform attached to it. That's when the 1,200-pound piece of equipment fell onto him. 
It took two hours before someone found a pool of blood, with him in the centre of it dead. It's unclear why with all that surveillance, he wasn't found until then. But regardless of why it took
so long, OSHA inspector John Stallone arrived the next day. 
He noticed that a pole that was designed to hold up the forklifts, as per safety regulations, wasn't used. Either you need to prop up the forks or, more ideally, never pass underneath them. The hydraulics can give out and the equipment on the forks can fall on you. 
Again, it's hard to speculate why Phillip didn't follow regulations, but to quote one Amazon employee, it's incredibly hard to meet rate while following all safety procedures. But on top of that, it was also discovered that there was no written record of Terry having received any formal training, so he may not have known what the safety procedures in a situation like this were. Inspector Stallone said that safety was second to production demands for Amazon. 
Due to the inadequate training, OSHA fined Amazon $28,000, a small fee for the $2.5 trillion company. Stallone did want to raise the fines, but got pushback. Feeling something was off, he started recording the conversations he had with his boss, rightly so, because eventually his boss asked him to shift the blame from Amazon to the employee and to lift the fine. 
This was in a recording he shared with Reveal, an independent news organisation. His boss wanted to partner with Amazon to help them become a leader in safety. She went on to say that Terry was likely on drugs, even though the coroner said there was nothing but nicotine in Terry's system. 
There was a reason for this, according to Stallone. Amazon was looking for a place to set up their new headquarters, and the city of Indianapolis was a finalist. Stallone had a meeting with the labour commissioner who stated it would be nice to get the headquarters, and asked Stallone to back off from the investigation or resign. 
Shortly after, Stallone's supervisor said he was going to be terminated for job performance issues, and so Stallone ended up resigning. Then he reached out to Reveal and provided the recordings, but sadly, nothing came out of the exposure. And a year later, with Stallone out of the way, Amazon signed a deal with OSHA to waive away all of the fines, and put the blame of this incident entirely on the deceased employee. 
And ready for the real kicker? In the end, Amazon didn't even choose Indianapolis for their headquarters. And it wasn't the only time OSHA was steeped in corruption with Amazon. Like during the blistering summer of 2022, when three workers died within the span of three weeks in Amazon warehouses across New Jersey. 
Temperatures during those three weeks were excessive, ranging from 90 to 97 degrees Fahrenheit. The first death took place on July 13th, the second day of the Amazon Prime Day sales event. During the pandemic, Amazon's 2022 Prime Day event garnered $11.9 billion, an increase of 62.8% from the previous year's revenue of $7.31 billion. 
So one could assume the workers at the Carteret New Jersey Fulfilment Centre probably had their hands full. Rafael Ronaldo Mottafria had been complaining about the heat in his
unconditioned workspace. Coworkers said he was pleading for fans, but he was told to work through it. 
Then he collapsed and passed away. Then on July 24th, at the Robinsville, New Jersey Amazon warehouse, Roger Bolin fell off a ladder and hit his head, dying in hospital three days later. And on August 4th, at a delivery facility in Monroe, a man named Eric Wadinsky was hospitalised and died four days after. 
But not much more can be found about this incident. OSHA investigated the three deaths. They claimed that Rafael had a previous heart condition which led to a heart attack, and Amazon wasn't held responsible again, even though heatstroke is known to cause heart attacks. 
Then when OSHA investigated the second incident of Roger, who fell off a ladder, it's reported that OSHA was denied access to the room where the accident occurred, until a few weeks later once the heat had died down. They determined that he had died of a seizure, but the doctors noted that he had an extremely high body temperature, and he had died of a brain injury due to the fall, so it could be possible that he was affected by the heat wave somehow. But regardless, Amazon wasn't deemed responsible. 
For the third, not much is known because no information was released, but as you might expect, Amazon wasn't held responsible. What's more odd is that OSHA's reports are supposed to be made public after their conclusion, yet only the report for their first death was released, which is why Warehouse Life, an Amazon workers' rights group, filed a request under the Freedom of Information Act to release the other reports on August 14th of 2024. OSHA never responded, which prompted the workers' rights group to file a lawsuit in November. 
As of February 2025, the reports still haven't been released. Amazon went on to state they bear no responsibility for these deaths and wish these tragic incidents wouldn't be twisted into something they weren't. But these deaths most likely could have been avoided if they had better working conditions, with proper air conditioning. 
And this wasn't the only time that Amazon has forced their employees to work through these intense weather conditions at the expense of their lives, all in the name of maximising profits. In fact, just eight months prior, Amazon warehouse workers were told to keep working during the deadliest December tornado outbreak in U.S. history. It was December 10th, 2021, in Edwardsville, Illinois, the day was warm for this time of year. 
The weather was ominous. The last three days were filled with warnings from meteorologists, with forecast models showing severe weather. But with the holidays looming, it was peak season, as Amazon referred to it, with temp workers hired and regular employees working overtime. 
There was even an added incentive for the drivers. If they could deliver 200 packages that day, they would get a $25 gift card. So it wasn't uncommon for the drivers to stuff their vehicles with
several hundred boxes at a time. 
One driver, Deontay Yancey, was out delivering packages, without his coat since it was oddly warm out. But as he dropped off the packages one by one, the customers would look at him surprised. Why are you still working, they would ask. 
All he could do was shrug and say, because Amazon wants me to. Perhaps it had something to do with the tornado warning put out that morning. The warning was set to a moderate risk, which is actually quite high, being level 4 out of 5. Damaging gusts, large hail, and a few long track tornadoes during the evening hours were predicted. 
All the while, Amazon warehouse workers and their drivers, under the watchful eye of their managers and AI surveillance, ready to catch any infraction, were still trudging along, trying to avoid bathroom breaks and meet their rate as time counted down on their displays. At 5.30 p.m., a tornado watch was fully in effect as supercell thunderstorms spread across Missouri, and by 7 p.m., they were making their way to the St. Louis metropolitan area, near the Edwardsville Amazon warehouses. Leslie Campbell, an Amazon worker who was off that day, 
used to chase tornadoes as a teenager, but this storm was unlike anything she had experienced before. 
It became pitch white from the rain, she explained. It had a weird feeling to it. It was around this time when sirens started to blare in nearby areas. 
Texts between an Amazon driver and her supervisor were obtained by Bloomberg News, revealing the frightening situation. At 7.08 p.m., the driver texted her supervisor, stating, Radio's been going off. The supervisor responded with, Okay, just keep driving. 
We can't just call people back for a warning unless Amazon tells us to do so. As the winds picked up, the storm got worse, and warnings were becoming more frequent. At 7.35 p.m., a tornado touched down in St. Charles County, 48 miles from the Amazon facility. 
This was the first one to hit the area, and many more tornadoes would come. In fact, it ended up being one of the deadliest Decembers on record. An EF-4 touched down a bit earlier, at 7.07 p.m., south of the facility in Arkansas. 
For reference, EF-5 is the highest the rating can go. This one in St. Charles was an EF-3. This file is longer than 30 minutes.
